title: 112_hr6262
content: The Act titled "Middle Class and Small Business Tax Relief Act of 2012" is an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Middle Class and Small Business Tax Relief Act of 2012" includes permanent extensions of tax relief for middle-class families, small businesses, and family farms from 2001 and 2003, as well as temporary extensions for 2009 tax relief, estate tax relief, and alternative minimum tax exemptions. The Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 is amended to apply to certain high-income taxpayers by adjusting income tax rates. The Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 is amended to adjust income tax rates for high-income taxpayers, including a reduction in the fourth rate bracket to 33 percent. The fourth rate bracket under the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 is reduced to 33 percent. The 36 percent rate of tax applies only to taxable income exceeding a certain amount in the bracket. Under the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001, the highest rate bracket has a 36 percent tax rate, which is reduced to 33 percent for applicable amounts. The tax rate on taxable income in the highest bracket is 35 percent for income below a certain threshold. The 39.6 percent tax rate applies to taxable income exceeding a certain threshold, known as the applicable amount, in the highest rate bracket. The 39.6 percent tax rate applies to taxable income exceeding the applicable threshold, which is the sum of the base amount and the small business and family farm. The base amount for small business and family farm income varies depending on the subsection, with $250,000 for subsection (a), $200,000 for subsections (b) and (c), and half the amount for subsection (d). The gross income of a taxpayer for a taxable year attributable to a small trade or business (excluding being an employee) or dividends, distributions, or interest from a small business is considered. Deductions properly allocable to this income are subtracted. The term 'small business' is defined as any corporation or partnership with less than 500 employees on business days during the taxable year. All persons treated as a single employer under specific sections are considered a single entity. An inflation adjustment is applied for taxable years beginning in this paragraph. In taxable years after 2012, dollar amounts are adjusted as in paragraph (1)(C), with a substitution of '2011' for '1992'. Section 68 is amended regarding itemized deductions, with changes to the applicable threshold. In taxable years after 2012, dollar amounts are adjusted with changes to the applicable threshold for itemized deductions. Amendments include striking subsections and redesignating paragraphs for the phaseout of deductions for personal exemptions. In taxable years after 2012, dollar amounts are adjusted with changes to the applicable threshold for itemized deductions. Amendments include striking subparagraphs and redesignating clauses for the phaseout of deductions for personal exemptions. The amendments made by this section, including an inflation adjustment, will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. SEC. 3. Permanent extension of 2003 tax relief for middle-class families, small businesses, and family farms. The Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 is repealed, with the effective date retroactively included. Additionally, a 20-percent capital gains rate is established for certain high-income individuals. The tax amount is determined based on taxable income, with a rate below 36 percent. The tax amount is determined based on taxable income, with rates below 36 percent. Subparagraphs (A) and (B) outline the adjusted net capital gain excess tax, while subparagraphs (C) and (D) detail the minimum tax percentages. The tax rates for adjusted net capital gain excess are outlined in subparagraphs (A) and (B), while subparagraphs (C) and (D) specify the minimum tax percentages. Conforming amendments increase the tax rate from 15 percent to 20 percent in various sections. Sections 1(h)(1)(B) and 55(b)(3)(B) are also amended to change the tax rate to 0 percent. The tax rates for adjusted net capital gain excess are amended to increase from 15 percent to 20 percent for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. Withholding amendments apply to amounts paid on or after January 1, 2013. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY EXTENSION OF 2009 TAX RELIEF. The text chunk discusses amendments to tax credits for the years 2012 and 2013, including the American Opportunity Tax Credit, Child Tax Credit, and Earned Income Tax Credit. The text chunk amends the rule disregarding refunds in federal programs and federally assisted programs, extending the deadline to December 31, 2013. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. SEC. 5 extends estate tax relief to December 31, 2013. SEC. 6 extends increased alternative minimum tax exemption amount. SEC. 6 temporarily extends the increased alternative minimum tax exemption amount for taxable years beginning in 2012. The amendment raises the exemption amount to $78,750 for single filers and $50,600 for joint filers. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. The amendment to section 26(a) extends to 2012, with changes applying to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011.
